title: Quadratic equation
text:
In <a href="algebra">algebra</a>, a quadratic equation (from the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> for "<a href="Square%20%28algebra%29">square</a>") is any <a href="equation">equation</a> that can be rearranged in standard form as 
where represents an <a href="Equation">unknown</a>, and , , and represent known numbers, where . If , then the equation is <a href="linear%20equation">linear</a>, not quadratic, as there is no formula_2 term. The numbers , , and are the "<a href="coefficient">coefficient</a>s" of the equation and may be distinguished by calling them, respectively, the "quadratic coefficient", the "linear coefficient" and the "constant" or "free term".
The values of that satisfy the equation are called "<a href="solution%20%28mathematics%29">solutions</a>" of the equation, and "<a href="zero%20of%20a%20function">roots</a>" or "<a href="zero%20of%20a%20function">zeros</a>" of the <a href="Expression%20%28mathematics%29">expression</a> on its left-hand side. A quadratic equation has at most two solutions. If there is only one solution, one says that it is a <a href="double%20root">double root</a>. If all the coefficients are <a href="real%20number">real number</a>s, there are either two real solutions, or a single real double root, or two <a href="complex%20number">complex</a> solutions. A quadratic equation always has two roots, if complex roots are included; and a double root is counted for two. A quadratic equation can be <a href="Factorization">factored</a> into an equivalent equation 
where and are the solutions for . <a href="Completing%20the%20square">Completing the square</a> on a quadratic equation in standard form results in the <a href="quadratic%20formula">quadratic formula</a>, which expresses the solutions in terms of , , and . Solutions to problems that can be expressed in terms of quadratic equations were known as early as 2000 BC.
Because the quadratic equation involves only one unknown, it is called "<a href="univariate">univariate</a>". The quadratic equation contains only <a href="exponentiation">powers</a> of that are non-negative integers, and therefore it is a <a href="polynomial%20equation">polynomial equation</a>. In particular, it is a <a href="degree%20of%20a%20polynomial">second-degree</a> polynomial equation, since the greatest power is two.
Solving the quadratic equation.
A quadratic equation with <a href="real%20number">real</a> or <a href="complex%20number">complex</a> <a href="coefficients">coefficients</a> has two solutions, called "roots". These two solutions may or may not be distinct, and they may or may not be real.
Factoring by inspection.
It may be possible to express a quadratic equation as a product . In some cases, it is possible, by simple inspection, to determine values of "p", "q", "r," and "s" that make the two forms equivalent to one another. If the quadratic equation is written in the second form, then the "Zero Factor Property" states that the quadratic equation is satisfied if or . Solving these two linear equations provides the roots of the quadratic.
For most students, factoring by inspection is the first method of solving quadratic equations to which they are exposed. If one is given a quadratic equation in the form , the sought factorization has the form , and one has to find two numbers and that add up to and whose product is (this is sometimes called "Vieta's rule" and is related to <a href="Vieta%27s%20formulas">Vieta's formulas</a>). As an example, factors as . The more general case where does not equal can require a considerable effort in trial and error guess-and-check, assuming that it can be factored at all by inspection.
Except for special cases such as where or , factoring by inspection only works for quadratic equations that have rational roots. This means that the great majority of quadratic equations that arise in practical applications cannot be solved by factoring by inspection.

<a href="Completing%20the%20square">Completing the square</a> can be used to <a href="Quadratic%20formula%23Derivation%20of%20the%20formula">derive a general formula</a> for solving quadratic equations, called the quadratic formula. A number of <a href="Quadratic%20formula%23Other%20derivations">alternative derivations</a> can be found in the literature. These proofs are simpler than the standard completing the square method, represent interesting applications of other frequently used techniques in algebra, or offer insight into other areas of mathematics.

Discriminant.
In the quadratic formula, the expression underneath the square root sign is called the "<a href="discriminant">discriminant</a>" of the quadratic equation, and is often represented using an upper case or an upper case Greek <a href="Delta%20%28letter%29">delta</a>:
A quadratic equation with "real" coefficients can have either one or two distinct real roots, or two distinct complex roots. In this case the discriminant determines the number and nature of the roots. There are three cases:
Thus the roots are distinct if and only if the discriminant is non-zero, and the roots are real if and only if the discriminant is non-negative.
Geometric interpretation.
The function is a <a href="quadratic%20function">quadratic function</a>. The graph of any quadratic function has the same general shape, which is called a <a href="parabola">parabola</a>. The location and size of the parabola, and how it opens, depend on the values of , , and . As shown in Figure 1, if , the parabola has a minimum point and opens upward. If , the parabola has a maximum point and opens downward. The extreme point of the parabola, whether minimum or maximum, corresponds to its <a href="vertex%20%28curve%29">vertex</a>. The "-coordinate" of the vertex will be located at formula_21, and the "-coordinate" of the vertex may be found by substituting this "-value" into the function. The "-intercept" is located at the point .
The solutions of the quadratic equation correspond to the <a href="root%20of%20a%20function">roots</a> of the function , since they are the values of for which . As shown in Figure 3, if the discriminant is positive, the graph touches the <a href="x-axis">-axis</a> at two points; if zero, the graph touches at one point; and if negative, the graph does not touch the -axis.

Avoiding loss of significance.
Although the quadratic formula provides an exact solution, the result is not exact if <a href="real%20number">real number</a>s are approximated during the computation, as usual in <a href="numerical%20analysis">numerical analysis</a>, where real numbers are approximated by <a href="floating%20point%20number">floating point number</a>s (called "reals" in many <a href="programming%20language">programming language</a>s). In this context, the quadratic formula is not completely <a href="numerical%20stability">stable</a>.
This occurs when the roots have different <a href="order%20of%20magnitude">order of magnitude</a>, or, equivalently, when and are close in magnitude. In this case, the subtraction of two nearly equal numbers will cause <a href="loss%20of%20significance">loss of significance</a> or <a href="catastrophic%20cancellation">catastrophic cancellation</a> in the smaller root. To avoid this, the root that is smaller in magnitude, , can be computed as formula_32 where is the root that is bigger in magnitude.
A second form of cancellation can occur between the terms and of the discriminant, that is when the two roots are very close. This can lead to loss of up to half of correct significant figures in the roots.
Examples and applications.
The <a href="golden%20ratio">golden ratio</a> is found as the positive solution of the quadratic equation formula_33
The equations of the <a href="circle">circle</a> and the other <a href="conic%20sections">conic sections</a>—<a href="ellipse">ellipse</a>s, <a href="parabola">parabola</a>s, and <a href="hyperbola">hyperbola</a>s—are quadratic equations in two variables.
Given the <a href="cosine">cosine</a> or <a href="sine">sine</a> of an angle, finding the cosine or sine of <a href="Bisection%23Angle%20bisector">the angle that is half as large</a> involves solving a quadratic equation.
The process of simplifying expressions involving the <a href="nested%20radical">square root of an expression involving the square root of another expression</a> involves finding the two solutions of a quadratic equation.
<a href="Descartes%27%20theorem">Descartes' theorem</a> states that for every four kissing (mutually tangent) circles, their <a href="radius">radii</a> satisfy a particular quadratic equation.
The equation given by <a href="Fuss%27%20theorem">Fuss' theorem</a>, giving the relation among the radius of a <a href="bicentric%20quadrilateral">bicentric quadrilateral</a>'s <a href="inscribed%20circle">inscribed circle</a>, the radius of its <a href="circumscribed%20circle">circumscribed circle</a>, and the distance between the centers of those circles, can be expressed as a quadratic equation for which the distance between the two circles' centers in terms of their radii is one of the solutions. The other solution of the same equation in terms of the relevant radii gives the distance between the circumscribed circle's center and the center of the <a href="excircle">excircle</a> of an <a href="ex-tangential%20quadrilateral">ex-tangential quadrilateral</a>.
<a href="Critical%20point%20%28mathematics%29">Critical points</a> of a <a href="cubic%20function">cubic function</a> and <a href="inflection%20point">inflection point</a>s of a <a href="quartic%20function">quartic function</a> are found by solving a quadratic equation.
History.
<a href="Babylonian%20mathematics">Babylonian mathematicians</a>, as early as 2000 BC (displayed on <a href="First%20Babylonian%20dynasty">Old Babylonian</a> <a href="clay%20tablet">clay tablet</a>s) could solve problems relating the areas and sides of rectangles. There is evidence dating this algorithm as far back as the <a href="Third%20Dynasty%20of%20Ur">Third Dynasty of Ur</a>. In modern notation, the problems typically involved solving a pair of simultaneous equations of the form:

In modern notation this means calculating formula_36, which is equivalent to the modern day <a href="quadratic%20formula">quadratic formula</a> for the larger real root (if any) formula_37 with , , and .
Geometric methods were used to solve quadratic equations in Babylonia, Egypt, Greece, China, and India. The Egyptian <a href="Berlin%20Papyrus%206619">Berlin Papyrus</a>, dating back to the <a href="Middle%20Kingdom%20of%20Egypt">Middle Kingdom</a> (2050 BC to 1650 BC), contains the solution to a two-term quadratic equation. Babylonian mathematicians from circa 400 BC and <a href="Chinese%20mathematics">Chinese mathematicians</a> from circa 200 BC used <a href="Dissection%20problem">geometric methods of dissection</a> to solve quadratic equations with positive roots. Rules for quadratic equations were given in "<a href="The%20Nine%20Chapters%20on%20the%20Mathematical%20Art">The Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art</a>", a Chinese treatise on mathematics. These early geometric methods do not appear to have had a general formula. <a href="Euclid">Euclid</a>, the <a href="Greek%20mathematics">Greek mathematician</a>, produced a more abstract geometrical method around 300 BC. With a purely geometric approach <a href="Pythagoras">Pythagoras</a> and Euclid created a general procedure to find solutions of the quadratic equation. In his work "<a href="Arithmetica">Arithmetica</a>", the Greek mathematician <a href="Diophantus">Diophantus</a> solved the quadratic equation, but giving only one root, even when both roots were positive.
In 628 AD, <a href="Brahmagupta">Brahmagupta</a>, an <a href="Indian%20mathematics">Indian mathematician</a>, gave the first explicit (although still not completely general) solution of the quadratic equation as follows: "To the absolute number multiplied by four times the [coefficient of the] square, add the square of the [coefficient of the] middle term; the square root of the same, less the [coefficient of the] middle term, being divided by twice the [coefficient of the] square is the value." ("Brahmasphutasiddhanta", Colebrook translation, 1817, page 346) This is equivalent to
The "<a href="Bakhshali%20Manuscript">Bakhshali Manuscript</a>" written in India in the 7th century AD contained an algebraic formula for solving quadratic equations, as well as quadratic <a href="indeterminate%20equation">indeterminate equation</a>s (originally of type ). <a href="Muhammad%20ibn%20Musa%20al-Khwarizmi">Muhammad ibn Musa al-Khwarizmi</a> (<a href="Persia">Persia</a>, 9th century), inspired by Brahmagupta, developed a set of formulas that worked for positive solutions. Al-Khwarizmi goes further in providing a full solution to the general quadratic equation, accepting one or two numerical answers for every quadratic equation, while providing geometric <a href="Mathematical%20proof">proofs</a> in the process. He also described the method of completing the square and recognized that the <a href="discriminant">discriminant</a> must be positive, which was proven by his contemporary <a href="%27Abd%20al-Ham%C4%ABd%20ibn%20Turk">'Abd al-Hamīd ibn Turk</a> (Central Asia, 9th century) who gave geometric figures to prove that if the discriminant is negative, a quadratic equation has no solution. While al-Khwarizmi himself did not accept negative solutions, later <a href="Mathematics%20in%20medieval%20Islam">Islamic mathematicians</a> that succeeded him accepted negative solutions, as well as <a href="irrational%20number">irrational number</a>s as solutions. <a href="Ab%C5%AB%20K%C4%81mil%20Shuj%C4%81%20ibn%20Aslam">Abū Kāmil Shujā ibn Aslam</a> (Egypt, 10th century) in particular was the first to accept irrational numbers (often in the form of a <a href="square%20root">square root</a>, <a href="cube%20root">cube root</a> or <a href="Nth%20root">fourth root</a>) as solutions to quadratic equations or as <a href="coefficient">coefficient</a>s in an equation. The 9th century Indian mathematician <a href="Sridhara">Sridhara</a> wrote down rules for solving quadratic equations.
The Jewish mathematician <a href="Abraham%20bar%20Hiyya">Abraham bar Hiyya Ha-Nasi</a> (12th century, Spain) authored the first European book to include the full solution to the general quadratic equation. His solution was largely based on Al-Khwarizmi's work. The writing of the Chinese mathematician <a href="Yang%20Hui">Yang Hui</a> (1238–1298 AD) is the first known one in which quadratic equations with negative coefficients of 'x' appear, although he attributes this to the earlier <a href="Liu%20Yi%20%28mathematician%29">Liu Yi</a>. By 1545 <a href="Gerolamo%20Cardano">Gerolamo Cardano</a> compiled the works related to the quadratic equations. The quadratic formula covering all cases was first obtained by <a href="Simon%20Stevin">Simon Stevin</a> in 1594. In 1637 <a href="Ren%C3%A9%20Descartes">René Descartes</a> published "<a href="La%20G%C3%A9om%C3%A9trie">La Géométrie</a>" containing the quadratic formula in the form we know today.
Advanced topics.
Alternative methods of root calculation.
Vieta's formulas.
"Vieta's formulas" (named after <a href="Fran%C3%A7ois%20Vi%C3%A8te">François Viète</a>) are the relations

For numerical computation, Vieta's formulas provide a useful method for finding the roots of a quadratic equation in the case where one root is much smaller than the other. If , then , and we have the estimate:

These formulas are much easier to evaluate than the quadratic formula under the condition of one large and one small root, because the quadratic formula evaluates the small root as the difference of two very nearly equal numbers (the case of large ), which causes <a href="round-off%20error">round-off error</a> in a numerical evaluation. The figure shows the difference between (i) a direct evaluation using the quadratic formula (accurate when the roots are near each other in value) and (ii) an evaluation based upon the above approximation of Vieta's formulas (accurate when the roots are widely spaced). As the linear coefficient increases, initially the quadratic formula is accurate, and the approximate formula improves in accuracy, leading to a smaller difference between the methods as increases. However, at some point the quadratic formula begins to lose accuracy because of round off error, while the approximate method continues to improve. Consequently, the difference between the methods begins to increase as the quadratic formula becomes worse and worse.
This situation arises commonly in amplifier design, where widely separated roots are desired to ensure a stable operation (see <a href="Step%20response">Step response</a>).
Trigonometric solution.
In the days before calculators, people would use <a href="mathematical%20table">mathematical table</a>s—lists of numbers showing the results of calculation with varying arguments—to simplify and speed up computation. Tables of logarithms and trigonometric functions were common in math and science textbooks. Specialized tables were published for applications such as astronomy, celestial navigation and statistics. Methods of numerical approximation existed, called <a href="prosthaphaeresis">prosthaphaeresis</a>, that offered shortcuts around time-consuming operations such as multiplication and taking powers and roots. Astronomers, especially, were concerned with methods that could speed up the long series of computations involved in <a href="celestial%20mechanics">celestial mechanics</a> calculations.

Geometric solution.
The quadratic equation may be solved geometrically in a number of ways. One way is via <a href="Lill%27s%20method">Lill's method</a>. The three coefficients , , are drawn with right angles between them as in SA, AB, and BC in Figure 6. A circle is drawn with the start and end point SC as a diameter. If this cuts the middle line AB of the three then the equation has a solution, and the solutions are given by negative of the distance along this line from A divided by the first coefficient or SA. If is the coefficients may be read off directly. Thus the solutions in the diagram are −AX1/SA and −AX2/SA.
The <a href="Carlyle%20circle">Carlyle circle</a>, named after <a href="Thomas%20Carlyle">Thomas Carlyle</a>, has the property that the solutions of the quadratic equation are the horizontal coordinates of the intersections of the circle with the <a href="horizontal%20axis">horizontal axis</a>. Carlyle circles have been used to develop <a href="ruler-and-compass%20construction">ruler-and-compass construction</a>s of <a href="regular%20polygon">regular polygon</a>s.
Generalization of quadratic equation.
The formula and its derivation remain correct if the coefficients , and are <a href="complex%20number">complex number</a>s, or more generally members of any <a href="field%20%28mathematics%29">field</a> whose <a href="characteristic%20%28algebra%29">characteristic</a> is not . (In a field of characteristic 2, the element is zero and it is impossible to divide by it.)
The symbol
in the formula should be understood as "either of the two elements whose square is , if such elements exist". In some fields, some elements have no square roots and some have two; only zero has just one square root, except in fields of characteristic . Even if a field does not contain a square root of some number, there is always a quadratic <a href="extension%20field">extension field</a> which does, so the quadratic formula will always make sense as a formula in that extension field.
